body:
Hi, could you just open a JIRA ticket? 
http://thrift.apache.org/docs/HowToContribute
Thanks!
yes, see my update
@Jens-G Thank you. I've raised a ticket here: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-2807
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-2809
commited, thanks!
please create Jira issue, see http://thrift.apache.org/docs/HowToContribute for details
Absolutely, closing this pull request. Will create a new one shortly with the proper branch name and issue reference. Thanks!
Thanks :)
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-2810
Tracked in THRIFT-2811. Next time please create the ticket yourself. Thank you.
tracked in THRIFT-2812

Thank you for the contributions!

May I ask two things?
(1) please [add JIRA tickets for both pull requests](http://thrift.apache.org/docs/HowToContribute)
(2) for this specific patch, a test case seems a good addition

Thanks again!
Alright, working on it.

Ok I checked the options to write a test.
It is quite complicated, because this bug only occurs when using real sockets.
So when using a Buffer for the tests it won't work.
I don't see a straightforward to write a mock either.
An integration test, would catch it immediately.
I see the lib has some kind of integration tests? right? 
I couldn't find out yet, how they work though.
Is there an integration test concept like in the node.js lib?
Have a look at the `multiplexed_protocol_test.go` file for an example how to achieve that.
I added binary support to client and to the web server. Now all integration tests pass.
Any build files to create the dependencies? Or do I have to do it by hand?
The usual makefiles, or what do you mean?
Issue has been created: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-2834

New PR.
See: https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/273
The JIRA for this pull request is thus: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-2840
Commited.
Commited.

Did you double check that data really comes as an Uint8Array and not a plain ArrayBuffer?
I have my doubts..

And to get more attention and to follow their contribution rules, you should file an issue on JIRA:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT/ and rename this PR to the name of the issue.

This was fixed in https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/273.
Can be closed.

I ran into this last night -- thanks for fixing @seanparsons!

I'm new to the Haskell/Thrift ecosystem -- will this fix be picked up by hackage or do I need to download the corresponding tarball from jenkins?
This will be picked up in the 0.9.3 release slated for early next month
Thanks!
This can be closed now because #276 was merged.

jira issue created.

yes, Browserify returns Uint8arrays, not a generic ArrayBuffer. you can see the code here:

https://github.com/substack/http-browserify/blob/master/lib/response.js#L108
Ok thanks for clarifying :-)
Created issue: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-2846
Reminder that this pull request can be closed.
The sooner the better, mostly because it's just completely broken as it is, I was wondering if a 0.9.2-1 release would be possible.

Tracked in THRIFT-2847 
Please have a look at http://thrift.apache.org/docs/HowToContribute
@Jens-G Thanks for making the PR in. Shall I close the PR or leave it as it is.

You can close it, it has been merged. 
At least theoretically the ASF bot should have auto-closed it anyway.
ah crap, messed up while updating to the recent changes. can someone close this PR and i'll open a new one with the appropriate changes?
another run of 'make style' will remove changes made by in this PR. If you want to increase readability of Go generator some bigger refactoring is needed - shorter functions, shorter << sequences.
I did that. I thought I had all the dependencies installed. But now i figured that I need clang-format right? ok I am going to work on that.

Wow ok now it works and yes it reverts everything. 
I'm going to change this, so it works with clang-format.

Thanks hcorg. I changed it now and ran the code with code-format. Rebased on current master. 
Should be committable.
I closed this PR and will provide a more comprehensive PR that cover more cases.
See https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/297
Usually you should be the one, with closing rights.
oh, i'm stupid :)
merged as part of 878483759c55365ef5da07ad8915e9a8e4af88d9
Is there any specific reason for adding an option for this?

any idea why the build fails?
https://travis-ci.org/apache/thrift/jobs/43262266

Yes, sorry for prematurely pushing the fix.

I'm having difficulty with Ubuntu 12.04 + trusty apt repo with Qt5 (on
travis).
It is specifically caused by "moc" executable installation failure (Failing
to find moc-qt5 and using qt4 version, hence the error).

I'm currently trying to fix it here, reducing to minimal set.
https://travis-ci.org/nsuke/thrift/builds

On Mon, Dec 8, 2014 at 12:45 AM, Roger Meier notifications@github.com
wrote:

> any idea why the build fails?
> https://travis-ci.org/apache/thrift/jobs/43262266
> 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/307#issuecomment-65941392.
thanks for the patch, please check this https://thrift.apache.org/docs/HowToContribute

> Is there any specific reason for adding an option for this?

My motivation for adding the functionality was avoiding copies for Thrift container types (e.g. list, set, map) when contemporary MoveConstructible STL implementations are available.

If you're asking specifically about making it an option, my aim was to avoid compatibility issues for pre-C++11 toolchains. Regardless, in discussion on [THRIFT-2836](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-2836), Konrad Grochowski expressed a preference to just fold this functionality into the C++V2 generator, so we can probably close this out.

> Is there any specific reason for adding an option for this?

If you're thinking of a reason to _not_ emit MoveConstructible/Assignable types, I'd certainly like to hear it.
I'm fine with this, could you fix the merge conflicts and I will commit.
Sounds good; fixed merge conflicts and ran `make style` for conformance.
The ci job is getting compiler failures; not sure what version of GCC Travis is running
I think this looks pretty good, will the addition of meck cause issues on the build system?  In the past when I include jsx it seemed to cause problems.
i don't think so. i think that had to do with the test platform shipping a messed up version of erlang that didn't work well with rebar

Hi, 

Firstly, thanks for the patch. 

Could you please ...
-  [File a JIRA ticket for it](http://thrift.apache.org/docs/HowToContribute)
- Explain the problem in more detail? Especially, why could it not work? I'm quite sure the code has been tested before it was committed ... [see here for details](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-812)

Have fun,
JensG

looking great Pascal!
+1
ps.: so I guess JS would be pretty straightforward to convert too as it also uses ant

check https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/THRIFT-2850

maybe those two changes can be merged

lib/php/test/Test/Thrift/Protocol/TestTJSONProtocol.php:103
this breaks the test suite _make check_ and what about _make cross_
2) test\Thrift\Protocol\TestTJSONProtocol::testStringMap_Write
Failed asserting that two strings are equal.

Great! 

+1
Merged as a195a2574ef9729da9be65283d29b87e39e8ebcb.

I started similar work at [1](https://github.com/jfarrell/thrift/tree/cmake) with a slightly different approach. I dont think that we should reference any autoconf from within cmake or try and work around it, but rather treat it as if it was not there and remove as we switch components over.

Great Jake, it looks like it shouldn't be hard to integrate your rb and py cmakelists onto this.
I think theses guys are using very good common practices for cmake, from what I have seen in the projects I've worked in the last years.

ps.: Hopefully everyone agrees that cmake shouldn't touch the autoconf stuff. It's looking like we are not that far from getting rid of it!

Note that current code uses mixed `#if` and `#ifdef` for `USE_..._Thread`
preprocessor macro tests and I unified those too.

These differs only when macro value is _not_ non-zero integer value
which has been resulting in inconsistent, broken configuration.
(For example, with `USE_STD_THREAD=0`
`#if !USE_STD_THREAD` passes whereas
`#ifndef USE_STD_THREAD` does not pass)

I can do it the other way around if there's already a prefered way.
+1 - this checks out.

Hi Jake

I had a look at your cmake branch. It looks good and the python and ruby integrations are nice. I added some comments to your [commit](https://github.com/jfarrell/thrift/commit/d4b1cd78ef0f789a671124e0a9c4c30254806ced#diff-15)
@jfarrell Regarding the referencing of autoconf I think the only place we do that is to get the version number. This was just done to avoid having to change the number in yet another place.

Hi

Any chance this change can be reviewed so that we can eliminate the need for a separate fork.
I can provide more background why this enhancement would benefit everyone's testing.
Thanks.

> we can eliminate the need for a separate fork.

I'm not sure how I should read this. Assuming this was just intended as a friendly remainder I'll take a look at the patch.
Isn't that a bit inconsistent to return either one address or the other? Why do we have to squash all into one function?
Ok, just committed this. Could you please close the PR manually? Thanks.

Hi Jens

I'm totally sorry if my tone was offensive. By fork, I don't mean to fork in the general sense, just the common Go practice of maintaining a copy of the source code in a subfolder. I am not a native speaker and thus I sometimes don't get the nuances right. : (
Also, thanks a lot for your efforts in maintaining this wonderful library which we have benefited from a lot. I truly appreciate the work in Thrift!

The build has been fixed (Travis failure is gcc internal error + make cross instability).
I also added CMake build.

TTransport inheritance made by TZmqClient is indeed incorrect, it doesn't override anything, only hiding non-virtual methods.

It should still work if used directly like TBinaryProtocolT<TZmqClient>, but does nothing when TTransport virtual methods are called.
Latter is what happens when "normal" TBinaryProtocol is used.

Since every one of my pending PRs conflicts with each other, I lumped them up here.
If you want to pick up in a different order or does not want to pull in any of them, let me know.

Obsoleted by this
https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/335

Obsoleted by this
https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/335

Obsoleted by this
https://github.com/apache/thrift/pull/335

Merged as https://github.com/apache/thrift/commit/2825664f25e084a922462c77f496d215e41251a9 https://github.com/apache/thrift/commit/6304a5341459eaa33e64aea80e0d0cc7d1b0b765 https://github.com/apache/thrift/commit/6622877a09a1ec6d38132bcdc9ac9a856d1c3931 https://github.com/apache/thrift/commit/a10697a9dbdfada8ed138f40c6ce5c1830c0daa8

Thanks for catching this. 

PS: I created THRIFT-2911 for you. Please try to follow [our few guidelines](http://thrift.apache.org/docs/HowToContribute) when submitting the next PR. Thank you

This is exactly the same patch as in PR #315 which has been [already commited to trunk](https://github.com/apache/thrift/commit/3e9c3a2af34fb8d2f37880e245e37e19dfb6edfa). There is no point in reviewing and committing it again.

Hi,

it is not only the merge conflicts, in general I have serious doubts. From my knowledge there are no plans to maintain such an old branch any further. You are welcome to explain your reasons for this PR on the [dev mailing list](https://thrift.apache.org/mailing), but - unless you come up with some very convincing reasons - this PR is very unlikely to be accepted.
After looking at your other PRs it becomes even more unlikely. Please close this PR.

Hi @cvlchinet, 

good work! Just one thing: What about changing the test case to use the existing OptionalRequiredTest.thrift IDL instead of adding a new IDL file?
This build has failed because of some jslint issues. Any hints how can I help resolving?

jslint is used via lib/js/test/build.xml which also runs the unit tests test.js/test.html

My favorite would be integration of your tests into test.js/test.html and use guessProtocolFactory within the server part https://github.com/apache/thrift/blob/master/lib/js/test/src/test/Httpd.java#L217
Thank you. I'll take a look at this.
@sectioneight looks like the build failed?
Indeed it did. Seems to be unrelated...
Merged as 8016af800ff19e2b67f691453c573f3d8f34211d
Merged as c444fb581d2157c260f36db091a7cdd4511c6e32, thanks :)

I've done a little bit more research into this. There's a major issue which will surface in the unit test once I can get it integrated. I've got the test properly integrated in the grunt task. What happens it that PhantomJS doesn't like the following expression:

```
String.fromCharCode.apply(null, new Uint8Array( buffer ) )
```

This has been described here: https://github.com/mozilla/pdf.js/issues/1955
The problem is, if I apply the "fix" mentioned in the comments, the test doesn't pass because unicode characters are decoded incorrectly. So, one way or another, the test will fail. I can see only one solution to this issue. I am going to close this pull request and provide the ThrifBinaryProtocol for JS as an external module to be added on top of Thrift library. Once this is done, I will post a link to the project here.
And the code: https://github.com/radekg/thrift-js-binary-protocol
